Award.AwardTitle: Scholarship fund for excellence in Computer Science and Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides a total of 120 scholarships to high-achieving financially disadvantaged undergraduate and masters students enrolled in computer science and mathematics at the University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras (UPR-RP). Since 98% of all students at UPR-RP receive some form of financial assistance, and 56% of undergraduates receive Pell grants, the need for these scholarships is great. Scholarship amounts range from $2,500 in the first year of study to $4,800 in the last year. The project is a model program which can be replicated to support financially disadvantaged students from underrepresented groups in different regions. Students will be recruited in the program through a series of presentations by the PIs and S-STEM Scholars. The PIs, with help from the S-STEM scholars, will host an event for middle and high school students that will highlight the impact of CS/Math in society. Graduate students will be recruited from within UPR-RP and at national meetings.

In addition to scholarship support, the project sponsors activities 1) to increase the awareness of scholars about opportunities for further studies and careers in industry, 2) to strengthen academic and professional skills of scholars, 3) to build a sense of community, 4) to highlight the social and applied aspect of computer science and mathematics, and 5) to support student learning through tutoring and mentoring. The overall goals of the project are to improve recruitment, retention, and preparation for employment or graduate school. The project prepares Puerto Rican students to work in two high demand disciplines, which helps meet the expanding need for computer science and mathematics professionals both locally and nationally.

The evaluation of this project will look at the retention to graduation rate, time to degree completion, and student progress after graduation. This data will be collected for recent graduates, current students (non- S-STEM Scholars), and S-STEM scholars. The rates will be compared for each group of students each year of the project to determine whether or not the program is effective.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project assigned a total of 124 scholarships to 64 to high-achieving financially disadvantaged undergraduate and graduate students in Computer Science and Mathematics at the University of Puerto Rico - Rio Piedras. In the vast majority of cases, the stipend allowed the students to focus on their studies and furthermore inspired them to pursue second degrees or extra coursework that improved their preparation for graduate school and/or the job market.  A retention of 94% was achieved among scholars, e.g. 60 of the 64 students either graduated from their program or are on track to graduate from the CS or Math programs. Of the 56 that graduated, 54 went on to Math/CS related jobs or graduate studies.                                                                                                                                                                                                                     

The scholarship program also provided one-to-one mentoring of the scholars with professors in Math and CS. This component was lauded by students and professors as essential to the success of the activities implemented by the program. As concluded by the external evaluator "mentoring positively impacted student performance, interest in research and graduate studies as well as dissemination and participation in academic internship opportunities and research. It also contributed positively to create an atmosphere of the academic community." 

A series of scientific and professional presentations sponsored by the project (27 in total) helped expose the scholars and general community to a very wide range of topics in CS and Math. They fostered collaborations amongst students, professors and the visiting scholars and motivated student involvement in undergraduate research and summer internships. Given our department's limited budget for visiting scholars, this project became one of the main sponsors of invited talks in the areas of CS and Math. 

The project also sponsored a total of 41 tutorships for barrier courses, thus broadening the impact to students beyond the scholars, since (a) the tutors were high-achieving students who were not necessarily financially disadvantaged but benefitted from a paid job in which they could gain practice in their field, and (b) the tutor sessions were open to all students taking the courses, not just Math and CS students.
